turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Jutlandic dialect.
turn.1: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.2: One of the hallmarks of the Scandinavian languages is the postclitic definite marker.
turn.3: What is the difference between them?
turn.6: In standard Danish this postclitic marker is only used when there is no adjective present, but if there is an adjective, a definite article is used instead: "den store mand" 'the big man'.
turn.7: What other things make the two languages unique?
turn.8: Further, standard Danish has a two gender system, distinguishing between the neuter ("intetkøn, -et)" and "other" ("fælleskøn, -en") genders.
turn.9: Is there anything else that is interesting?
turn.10: In Jutland, however, very few dialects match the standard in these two aspects.
turn.11: Why do they match the standard?
turn.12: There are dialects with one, two and three genders, as well as dialects lacking the postclitic definite marker entirely.
